• The main content comprises several different topics in a dual pager setup that can be navigated using the side arrows, or through the menu that pops up when clicking the page title between them. Please note that there is some bug in ViewPager2 that can cause things to go out of sync if using the menu in a debug build. Release build works fine, somehow.

• The description at the bottom of each page is scrollable, and can also be long-pressed to open a dialog with the same text in a larger font.

• The shadows throughout this demo have been darkened quite a bit beyond normal, simply to make it easier to see what's happening. This was done by increasing the light source alphas in the relevant theme attributes, so that's where to look, if you'd like to adjust them.

• Please note that on some of the earlier supported Android versions, certain things just don't work in general; e.g., you cannot have both rounded corners and transparency on Lollipop 21, so Intro's target isn't see-through on that version.

• This demo was designed to fit comfortably on medium phone sizes only, so it might not look that great on other configurations. Apologies, if that's an inconvenience.
Only relevant on API levels >=30\nCurrent API level: %1d

The rounded rectangle in the upper left frame is a plain <View> with a translucent background and adjustable elevation. It can be long-clicked to drag-and-drop between the two frames, as a simple demonstration of how the clipped shadow will automatically move to its target's new parent. (The drag shadow is a plain gray round rectangle, by the way, since we can't draw these shadows there.)

The "Clip shadow" switch is simply calling clipOutlineShadow = isChecked on the target View, and the radio buttons determine which item the color controls affect: the View itself, or its shadow.

On API levels <28, the shadow color is handled with the color compat feature. As for API level 28 (Pie) itself, if shadow color doesn't work on that version, please see the relevant entry in the README's Project notes section.

This page shows how the clipped shadows automatically animate and transform along with their targets, even though they're not intrinsic to them.

The top View can be swiped side to side in a MotionLayout that's simultaneously modifying the target's color, scale, and rotation.

The bottom half demonstrates some FloatingActionButtons and a Snackbar inside a CoordinatorLayout, showing how the shadows integrate well with standard animations.

The three ShadowPlanes are demonstrated here, along with the defects possible with the Foreground and Background types.

The setups above are both similar: a plain gray View with a low elevation on the left, the blue target in the middle with a medium elevation, and another gray one on the right with the highest elevation.

The top panel is another MotionLayout with a swipeable target, and the shadows turned off on the gray Views, to make it easier to watch the shadow on the moving target. The bottom panel is a static arrangement with the target and siblings intersecting, and all the shadow intact.

The library also offers a few different ways to apply the fix, other than through direct use in code.

• There are several customized subclasses of the common recycling ViewGroups like RecyclerView and ListView that automatically enable the fix on each of their children, and thereafter handle the shadows' attach/detach behavior more efficiently than would normally happen. The RecyclerView on the left is one of those custom classes.

• Most other common ViewGroups also have available subclasses that will recognize and handle custom shadow attributes on children in layout XML, allowing you to keep it out of the code entirely. For example, the three FABs above on the right have their shadows fixed with an XML attribute, inside a <ClippedShadowsConstraintLayout>.

• Lastly, there are inflation helpers that are designed to "plug in" to an Activity's layout inflation pipeline to look for the aforementioned attributes without using the custom subclasses, or to apply the fix to tags that match rules defined in code or XML. This is a somewhat niche tool that I don't foresee being of much use to others, so I don't really push it anymore, but it's still in the library, though all of its docs are only in the wiki.

Here we\'re demonstrating the ViewPathProvider interface, and how even simple shapes like a square with one round corner cannot be fixed automatically on API levels 30 and up.\n\nThe library also includes a concrete implementation that will allow the fix to work automatically with ViewGroups that have a MaterialShapeDrawable background, as many of the standard library ones do.

The ShadowDrawable class is included as a convenient way to draw these shadows manually without to having to mess with the core module, but there are a few ways in which it does not act like a regular Drawable at all. The full details are in the README; this page demonstrates only the main caveat to note when using this.

Though we're able to clip these shadows, they're still kind of happening in a completely separate draw that's behind all the stuff we're drawing ourselves with the SDK primitives. Because of that, it's possible to get a shadow out of sync with its clipped area, causing the artifacts to become visible out of bounds of the clip.

If you're doing anything more than relatively basic, static draws, extra care should be taken to ensure that the clip is invalidated when any relevant shadow properties are changed.

For those situations where a layer is required – such as with all color compat shadows, or with certain setups on older API levels – it behaves more like a regular drawable, and just won't redraw at all until invalidated.
This page contains a ComposeView showing a LazyColumn() of translucent items, FloatingActionButton(), a regular Button(), and a specially shaped Card() all using clippedShadow() to replace shadow().

The panel at the top here shows two identical Views side by side, the left one with native shadow colors, and the right one using color compat. You can switch the white backgrounds off in order to view the whole shadows to see how the colors are applied.

The color compat mechanism has to tint the shadow as a whole, so we we're not able to apply the ambient and spot colors separately. The library includes optional helpers to blend the ambient and spot colors you would use on newer versions, into a single value to use with color compat.

As noted in the README, messing with the ambient and spot colors' alphas does not work well with the current blend calculation. I would imagine that most everyone uses full-alpha colors for these anyway, since a "non-opaque" light source doesn't really make sense, yeah?

You can switch between identical setups in both frameworks, View and Compose, to compare. When switching, the panels fade in and out in place, to show that the results are identical in both. It might be hard to spot.

Color compat has also been added to the ShadowDrawable class.\n\nIt\'s also now possible to create an unclipped version so the clipping operation can be skipped if it\'s not needed for a particular setup; e.g., if you\'re going to draw an opaque region over it anyway.

These lists are set up to be far more intensive that what your average app would entail, as far as the expensive operations that these shadows can involve.

The left list is a ShadowsRecyclerView with an Adapter that sets a different translucent background on each item along with a clipped shadow using color compat, and evenly distributes the shadows across all three ShadowPlanes. The group itself takes over the Inline shadow draws, so it's also modifying the normal child draw routine, and there's a separate compositing layer for each item you can see, plus a few more off-screen.

The setup on the right is the Compose analog of the View version, and it consists of LazyColumn() that sets a clippedShadow() with an interpolated color compat, also with a separate compositing layer for each item.
